title: USS Dolphin (SP-318)
text:
USS "Dolphin" (SP-262) was the proposed name and designation for a <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="patrol%20vessel">patrol vessel</a> that the Navy never actually acquired.
"Dolphin" was built as the commercial <a href="steam">steam</a> <a href="fishing%20vessel">fishing vessel</a> "Virginia" at <a href="Pocomoke%20City%2C%20Maryland">Pocomoke City, Maryland</a>. She was of the "<a href="menhaden%20fisherman">menhaden fisherman</a>" design. She was rebuilt in 1911, and at some point between 1908 and 1917 was renamed "Dolphin".
The U.S. Navy considered acquiring "Dolphin" in 1917 for <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> service as a patrol vessel and assigned her the <a href="section%20patrol">section patrol</a> number SP-318. Although reported by some contemporary sources as having been placed in <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commission</a> in February 1919 as USS "Dolphin" (SP-318), she in fact appears never to have been acquired by the Navy and to have remained in <a href="civilian">civilian</a> hands.
"Dolphin" should not be confused with <a href="USS%20Dolphin%20%28PG-24%29">USS "Dolphin" (Gunboat No. 24)</a>, a <a href="gunboat">gunboat</a> and <a href="dispatch%20vessel">dispatch vessel</a> in commission at the time, or with , a patrol vessel in commission during 1918.
